user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CreateSocketName:
```c
void OS_CreateSocketName(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, const char *parent_name)
{
    size_t                       len;
    uint16                       port;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *sock;

    sock = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, *token);

    if (OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name), Addr) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        sock->stream_name[0] = 0;
    }
    if (OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl(&port, Addr) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        len = OS_strnlen(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name));
        snprintf(&sock->stream_name[len], sizeof(sock->stream_name) - len, ":%u", (unsigned int)port);
    }

    if (parent_name)
    {
        /* Append the name from the parent socket. */
        len = OS_strnlen(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name));
        snprintf(&sock->stream_name[len], sizeof(sock->stream_name) - len, "-%s", parent_name);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_CreateSocketName:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
int32 OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl(char *buffer, size_t buflen, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    const void *                  addrbuffer;
    const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in.sin_addr;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_addr;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    if (inet_ntop(Accessor->sa.sa_family, addrbuffer, buffer, buflen) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl(uint16 *PortNum, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    in_port_t                     sa_port;
    const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            sa_port = Accessor->sa_in.sin_port;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            sa_port = Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_port;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    *PortNum = ntohs(sa_port);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
static inline size_t OS_strnlen(const char *s, size_t maxlen)
{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);
    if (end != NULL)
    {
        /* actual length of string is difference */
        maxlen = end - s;
    }
    return maxlen;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
sock = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, *token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown code: token is declared as const OS_object_token_t * so the expression *token has type const OS_object_token_t and &( *token ) yields a const OS_object_token_t *. The macro expansion therefore does not discard const qualifiers, and the returned ptr (sock) is non-const intentionally because the function modifies the stream record (so const would be inappropriate). Potential violation scenario (hypothetical): if OS_ObjectIndexFromToken (or the macro) were declared to take a non-const OS_object_token_t * and thus required a non-const pointer, then passing &( *token ) would discard the const qualifier and would violate the intent of Rule 8.13.
